Task.TaskDescription: Problem: An oil tanker is a ship that carries oil from one port to another. This particular NEWLINE oil tanker is small, so it only has 2 tanks. One tank is in the front of the ship and the NEWLINE other is in the rear. The front tank holds 100000 gallons of oil when completely full and the NEWLINE rear tank also holds 100000 gallons of oil when full. This ship had a problem with its rear NEWLINE tank, which has just been fixed. While it was being fixed, the front tank was being filled. At NEWLINE this time, the front tank has 45000 gallons in it and the rear tank has 500. Thus, the ship has NEWLINE much more weight in the front than the rear and is not riding with an "even keel". That is, its NEWLINE front is pointing slightly downwards. This makes sense, because the ratio of the rear tanks' NEWLINE content to the front tank's content is 500/45000, which is 0.01. This ratio should be 1.0, so NEWLINE that the ship rides at an even keel. After a quick calculation, the dock master orders the NEWLINE dockworkers to add 5000 gallons per hour to the front tank and 15000 gallons an hour to the rear NEWLINE tank. He figures that this will bring the weight distribution to equality in a few hours, and NEWLINE then the ship will ride at an even keel. NEWLINE NEWLINE Goal: Graph the ratio of the rear tank's content to the front tank's content over a 6-hour period.

Function: ratio of rear to front tank = rear tank / front tank

 Given: added to rear tank hourly = 15000 
 Accumulator: front tank = front tank + added to front tank hourly Initial value = 45000 
 Given: added to front tank hourly = 5000 
 Given: capacity of front tank = 100000 
 Given: capacity of rear tank = 100000
